data.title: HAS ANYONE SEEN MY CAMEL?

data.text:
Camel fans have had the hump for years,

since their heroes have gone into semiretirement

and spent three decades

under the rock radar. While the likes of

King Crimson, Yes, Pink Floyd and Genesis have

been given their dues, Camel remained in the

shadows. Yet the band produced some of the finest

albums in prog and went on to influence neo-proggers

such as Galahad and Pendragon, and

latter-day acts like The Flower Kings and Opeth.

This year, six of their albums have been given the

expanded, deluxe treatment, to remind us of what a

great band they really were.

Camel evolved from a beat outfit formed in

Guildford in 1964 by the Latimer brothers, Ian

(bass) and Andrew (guitar/vocals). Along with

chums Alan Butcher (drums) and Richard Over

(guitar) they operated as The Phantom Four and,

when Over left and was replaced by Graham

Cooper, they became Strange Brew (after The

Cream’s song). In summer 1968, Latimer and

Cooper departed for family life, and an ad in The

Surrey Advertiser led them to bassist Doug Ferguson.

Ferguson introduced his colleagues to a 14-year old

drummer, Andy Ward, and impressed by his chops,

he was recruited in January 1969.

The Brew, as they became, recorded a demo of

The Cream’s Crossroads for DJM, who urged them

to take a gig backing keyboardist/singer Philip

Goodhand-Tait. In 1971, they played on his I Think

I’ll Write A Song, but it failed to take off and the trio

were dropped by the label. However, an ad in The

Melody Maker that September led them to recruit a

keyboardist of their own, Peter Bardens. He’d played with Shotgun Express, Van Morrison’s Them and

Peter B’s Looners, and cut two Transatlantic solo

albums (The Answer, and an eponymous effort, both

RRPG-rated at £30). In October, the four played as

Peter Bardens’ On, before changing their name to

Camel. Their first show under that banner was in

December, supporting Wishbone Ash.

Touring through 1972 and winning over a

growing student following, that August they were

picked up by MCA. Despite auditioning 30 singers,

they pressed on without a frontman. They swiftly

recorded a single, Never Let Go, issued that

November, and an impressive eponymous debut set

was cut in 12 days, which Latimer subsequently

recalled was “a bloody nightmare”! It featured rock

songs such as Mystic Queen and instrumental jams

with shifting time-signatures, notably in 6/8, such as

Arubaluba and, er, Six Ate. However, when Camel’s

debut was issued in time for Christmas 1973, it

failed to set the world alight. At the start of 1974,

they were dropped by MCA and signed with the

more prog-friendly Decca.

After nine months on the road, Camel retired to

the studio to cut Mirage, in March 1974. Its sleeve

featured a version of the US Camel cigarette brand’s

packaging, but the company threatened to sue, so it

was dropped in that territory, while a European

marketing deal cut by the band’s management

without their knowledge saw free cigarettes given

away with the album, prompting Bardens to suggest

renaming one song Twenty Sticks Of Cancer.

Despite the rancour that this caused, the set

consolidated their prog credentials, mixing short

energetic numbers such as Freefall with flowing

extended pieces, including the gentle Lady Fantasy

and Nimrodel/The Procession/The White Rider,

which was inspired by J.R.R. Tolkien’s The Lord Of

The Rings. Sounds noted, “you don’t listen to a band

like Camel for quick thrills. You really have to hear

them a few times before the music begins to register.

All those long and delicately arranged instrumental

passages burn slow, but once the melodies are in

your head, they don’t rub out easily”.

Ferguson suggested that their third outing should

be a concept album based on another book, and

Bardens nominated Herman Hesse’s Siddhartha.

Demos were cut in June 1974, but the concept was

abandoned as unworkable. Hence, Ferguson

proposed Paul Gallico’s The Snow Goose novella and,

after a seven-week US tour with Wishbone Ash,

Latimer and Bardens set to work on it. In the

interim, they gained street cred by playing the

Greasy Truckers’ Party at London’s Camden

Dingwalls club that October, alongside the likes of

space-rockers Gong and Henry Cow.

Camel debuted their Music Inspired By The Snow

Goose in September 1974 and the resultant

instrumental opus, realised in 16 orchestral

movements, saw them make No. 22 in spring 1975.

Containing shimmering, flute-led passages like the

title, it won them Melody Maker’s Brightest Hope

Of 1975 accolade. That October, it was rendered

with the London Symphony Orchestra at the Royal

Albert Hall. (It was issued in April 1978 as the 2-LP

A Live Record).

1976’s Moonmadness features songs inspired by

the band members’ personalities, notably Chord

Change (Bardens), Another Night (Ferguson), Air

Born (Latimer) and Lunar Sea (Ward). The overall

feel was less flighty and more akin to the heavier

pomp efforts of Pink Floyd, as demonstrated on

Song Within A Song. The set won over US critics

and bettered its predecessor in the UK charts,

notching up a No. 15 placing.

That September’s Rain Dances saw Latimer,

Bardens, Ward and Sinclair (on lead vocals) assisted

by numerous guests and made No. 20. Producer

Rhett Davis brought in recent collaborator, ex-Roxy

Music’s Brian Eno, who supplied electronic sound

effects to supplement the band’s jazzy orchestral

arrangements. Fans and critics alike praised the likes

of the prog Unevensong, Skylines and the title track,

while punchier elements included Metrognome.

Breathless appeared within a year of its

predecessor, combining soft-rockers such as Echoes

with Canterbury whimsy, such as Sinclair’s belchladen

Down On The Farm. However, in July, just

prior to another tour, Bardens walked out, going on

to play with Van Morrison on Wavelength, as well as

his solo Heart To Heart. Following a three-month

tour, Breathless hit No. 26 and Dave Sinclair left,

Richard accompanying him. Thus, Happy The

Man’s Kit Watkins took over on keyboards, while

the ironically-named Colin Bass wielded the bass

guitar.

In between heavy touring, the more accessible,

Rupert Hine-produced I Can See Your House From

Here was cut. It featured proggier moments such as

Ice, but also more pop-rock, as well as three Colins:

Bass, Mel and Genesis’ Phil (on percussion). It

peaked at No. 45.

Watkins departed just before the band entered the

studio to record their next concept piece, Nude, and

Cockney Rebel’s Duncan Mackay filled in. Issued in

January 1981, the new opus focused on the true

story of a Japanese soldier left on an island after

World War 2. It made No. 34.

Watkins returned for a world tour and promptly

left after its conclusion, Ward’s alcohol and drug

misuse having led to a suicide attempt, followed by a

sabbatical. Bass followed suit and, under pressure

from the label for a radio-friendly single, Latimer

called The Alan Parsons Project’s singer Chris

Rainbow to help out with The Single Factor.

Emerging in April 1982, the platter made No. 57,

and both Bass and Ward returned to the fold for

another world tour. However, citing his distaste for

the heavy workload and the music industry in general,

Ward stood down in January 1983 (though fans were

told that he’d injured his hand – he eventually took

up market gardening in Suffolk), and he was replaced

by Jethro Tull’s Paul Burgess, while Kayak’s Ton

Scherpenzeel took over on keyboards.

Their collective APP-sounding effort, March

1984’s Stationary Traveller, was inspired by the

divided city of Berlin and reached No. 57. A May

show at London’s Hammersmith Odeon recorded by

PMV (featuring Strictly Come Dancing judge Bruno

Tonioli), became the 1985 Pressure Points album and

video, featuring Bardens, Collins and keyboardist

Richie Close, who died a few months after from

Legionnaire’s Disease.

At that point, Camel were hit by a law-suit brought

by their ex-manager, Geoff Jukes. Latimer, Bardens,

Ward and Ferguson then filed their own action

against Gama (Decca Europe) for unpaid royalties, a

dispute that was resolved in their favour in March

1985, freeing them from their Decca contract. The

Collection and A Compact Compilation followed later

that year, but it was not until 1988 that the Jukes case

was resolved to Latimer’s satisfaction, and the long

struggle took its toll. Ward also ‘officially’ left the

band, never to play with them again.

After futile attempts to gain a UK record deal, a

disillusioned Latimer decided to move to the US. He

set up Camel Productions, hoping to issue the longgestating

Dust And Dreams, which was inspired by

John Steinbeck’s The Grapes Of Wrath. It was partly

re-recorded in 1990 and was eventually self-released in

September 1992, following the Landscapes 2-CD

collection of 1991. The new studio set comprised

superlative atmospheric, mainly instrumental

numbers. Soon afterwards, reissues of the some of the

band’s catalogue and an Official Bootleg series of

recordings appeared.

Warning: Camel On The Road 1972 kicked things

off and, by August 1992, that’s where the band were

once more. Burgess, Bass and Fish keyboardist Mickey

Simmonds were roped in by Latimer, and a show at

Enschede, The Netherlands, was captured as the Never

Let Go (Live 92) 2-CD and unveiled in November

1993 (complementing the Echoes 2-CD anthology).

However, in March 1993, Latimer’s father died,

and Andy spent much of 1994 researching his

genealogy for the personal Harbour Of Tears concept

album about the Irish emigrations of the 19th century

via Cobh Harbour to the USA. In March 1995,

Latimer returned to the studio with Bass, Simmonds,

Paton, McKenna and San Francisco drum instructor

John Xepoleas. The Celtic-toned set, issued in January

1996, included The Hour Candle (A Song For My

Father).

Following 1997’s vintage On The Road 1981,

Latimer issued 1998’s Coming Of Age – Live, recorded

the previous March in Hollywood, with Bardens

watching in the wings.

Soon afterwards, Bass gave Latimer a copy of the

World Music – A Rough Guide book and he took

inspiration from its entry about Arab musical poetry,

rajaz, which was spontaneously sung to the rhythm

of camel footsteps. Scherpenzeel contributed via

email some mesmeric key patterns that

supplemented the guitar soundscapes of Latimer,

Bass and Stewart and, by October 1999, Rajaz was

ready. Another tour was planned, but just before it

kicked off in spring 2000, Stewart dropped out to

run a drum shop in Edinburgh. Clive Bunker (ex-

Jethro Tull) was approached to join Camel, but

rehearsals didn’t work out, so LeBlanc’s compatriot,

Denis Clement, stepped in. They hit the road in

August 2000 and, in March 2001, Camel at last

received some of the recognition that they deserved,

featuring as they did in Channel 4 TV’s Top 10 Of

Prog Rock.

Within a year, Peter Bardens died of cancer in Los

Angeles in January 2002, and The Paris Collection

live album, recorded at the Bataclan in September

2000, appeared, along with Lunar Sea: An Anthology

1973-85. In August 2002, the band’s A Nod And A

Wink, based on the events of 9/11, saw Latimer,

Bass, LeBlanc and Clement joined by drummer

Terry Carleton. A Farewell Tour in 2003 brought

Scherpenzeel back to the fold in Europe, and the

band headlined NEARFest, with Tom Brislin from

Spiraling on keys. However, after toying with the

idea of recording an acoustic set, Latimer, suffering

from the rare, chronically fatiguing blood disorder,

myelofibrosis, took time out, before issuing the

Footage I and II DVDs in October 2005, and

relocating to the UK a year later. Latimer’s illness was

revealed via the band’s website in May 2007, as well

as his intention to produce another Camel album.

After stem cell replacement at the end of the year, he

was recovering and planning for the future, while

Eclectic issued 2-CD deluxe editions through 2009.
